thread.title: UPDATE 1-Bank of Portugal turns to second bidder for Novo Banco
thread.title_full: UPDATE 1-Bank of Portugal turns to second bidder for Novo Banco | Reuters

author: Reuters
title: UPDATE 1-Bank of Portugal turns to second bidder for Novo Banco
text:
(Updates with Apollo, Fosun)
LISBON, Sept 1 (Reuters) - The Bank of Portugal is to start negotiations with U.S. fund Apollo Global Management on the sale of state-rescued Novo Banco after exclusive talks with China's Anbang Insurance Group Co were unsuccessful, two sources familiar with the talks said.
The Bank of Portugal said in a statement: "As no agreement has been reached, the Bank of Portugal decided today to end those negotiations and invite the second-placed potential buyer into negotiations."
The sources said the central bank had invited Apollo for talks. "The second candidate invited (to exclusive talks) is Apollo," one of the sources said.
Novo Banco is the "good bank" carved out of Banco Espirito Santo (BES) after a 4.9 billion euro ($5.52 billion) bailout in August 2014. BES, then Portugal's second largest bank, collapsed under the weight of its founding family's debts. It was the country's biggest ever financial collapse.
Portuguese authorities hope to sell Novo Banco to recover some of the money and started the sale process in December and then opened exclusive talks with Anbang earlier in August.
The Bank of Portugal said a third-placed bid, made by China's Fosun International, was still valid. Fosun would only be invited for talks if negotiations with the second-placed bidder also failed.
A Fosun spokesperson said: "After the decision of Banco de Portugal, Fosun would like to reaffirm its strong commitment to Portugal ... We will continue to pay attention to new investment opportunities."
Neither Apollo nor Anbang were immediately available for comment.
Analysts have said bids for Novo Banco could be limited by concerns about legal challenges launched by holders of commercial paper issued by the Espirito Santo group which was sold to BES clients.
Although most of the BES rescue package came from public funds, the capital came via the Bank Resolution Fund, the joint responsibility of Portugal's banks, meaning any losses on the sale would be incurred by banks. ($1 = 0.8878 euros) (Reporting By Sergio Goncalves and Axel Bugge , editing by Shrikesh Laxmidas and Jane Merriman)
